awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Modeling Advanced LIGO Gravitational Wave Sources and their Electromagnetic Counterparts
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support a multifaceted theoretical study of the mergers of various types of compact objects such as neutron stars. Understanding the full sequence of events in these mergers is a great interdisciplinary challenge of high current interest.  The work will model binary formation and gravitational wave-driven inspiral; the hydrodynamics of mergers; the viscous, thermal and nuclear evolution of the post merger remnant; the general relativistic radiation hydrodynamics of the collapse to neutron stars and black holes (with its associated gravitational wave signals); and the nuclear and radiation hydrodynamics of the unbound ejecta that produces observable electromagnetic (light, radio wave, etc.) signals.  

A major motivation is to model both gravity wave and electromagnetic signatures from these mergers. The two types of signatures provide important information about different regions of the sources. Gravitational waves will determine the 'engine' of the sources, their masses, spins, and inclinations. The electromagnetic signals will provide the precise locations, compositions, and their relation to the rest of astrophysics (nucleosynthesis, pulsars, magnetars, transients, Type Ia supernovae, formation rates and progenitors). 

The project will contribute to the training of graduate students and in regular student exchanges between the participating institutions. Members of the research team will continue their efforts to give non-technical lectures for the public, high schools and undergraduate institutions, and consult on curricula, films, TV and radio. The results of this research, on topics that tend to generate broad interest (stellar collisions, explosions, collapse to black holes, gravitational waves in space-time), will be incorporated into these activities. The team will also make the results from this study widely available to the astrophysics community.

Intellectual Merit

This past year, Advanced LIGO opened the gravitational wave view of
the Universe.  A major goal in the coming years is to simultaneously
see the same astrophysical source with gravitational wave and
electromagnetic telescopes.  This would provide far more information
than either view alone can provide.  Our collaboration focused on
developing improved theoretical predictions of the electromagnetic
emission associated with gravitational wave sources.

In the course of this work, we developed the leading model for the
electromagnetic counterparts to mergers of neutron stars.  The
merger ejects some matter from the system, which produces a faint
supernova like source of optical-infrared light.  We calculated how
much mass is ejected from neutron star mergers, the composition of the
outflow, and the resulting properties of the electromagnetic
counterpart.  Matter ejected from neutron star mergers in this manner
may be the primary place in the Universe that some of the heavy
elements in the periodic table are produced, including gold and a
number of elements that are important in modern technology.

We also showed how white dwarf mergers with a total mass above the maximum mass of a white dwarf ultimately collapse to form a neutron star,
significantly changing the communities view of how this happens. 

In more detail, our major scientific results include the following:

1.  White Dwarf Mergers and Accretion Induced Collapse

We demonstrated that white dwarf mergers with masses above the Chandrasekhar mass collapse to form a neutron star via a channel that no one had anticipated in the previous literature on this problem.  In particular, rather than the star collapsing via electron captures as previously argued, fusion proceeds all the way to iron, generating an unusual low mass iron core.  We are now prepared to calculate the observational signatures (electromagnetic and gravitational wave) of the resulting iron core collapse and supernova.   

As part of this work, we also developed improved models for the accretion induced collapse (AIC) of white dwarfs to neutron stars (which can still occur in single degenerate scenarios).   AIC is caused when electron captures on Neon and Magnesium rob the white dwarf of pressure support, leading to collapse.   We have developed and implemented new methods of calculating the evolution of AIC progenitors in the open source stellar evolution code MESA -- these tools are now available to the broader community.  We have carried out calculations of the evolution of white dwarfs towards AIC, showing for the first time how the electron captures initiate a thermal runaway in the core of the white dwarf.   

2.  Neutron Star Mergers

We have carried out  theoretical predictions of the expected electromagnetic emission from accretion disks left after neutron star mergers.   The emission is produced in outflows created during the merger; the primary uncertainties are in the thermodynamics and composition of outflows from the accretion disk.   We showed that black hole spin leads to more matter ejected and thus a brighter electromagnetic counterpart.   In ongoing work, we are carrying out the first self-consistent magnetohydrodynamic simulations of the long-time evolution of the accretion disk left after neutron star mergers.

We further studied neutrino transport in post-merger accretion disks. Weak interactions alter the composition of the debris disks formed in compact binary mergers, and so strongly affect the color of the associated electromagnetic counterpart.  We developed a Monte Carlo neutrino transport code and used to calculate detailed models of post-merger disks. The calculations highlight the limitations of previous approximate transport schemes, and provide insight into the role neutrinos play in setting the composition of outflows and the energetics of GRB jets.

We further studied the opacities of the material ejected in mergers and its dependence on composition. We showed that the unusual heavy elements produced in these events have a much higher opacity than previous thought. We found that this high opacity led to transients that were dimmer, longer-lasting, and much redder than previously believed. The opacity was sensitive to the abundance of heavier elements in the ejecta, and hence the conditions of the outflow. The color of the transient thus carries information as to the physical condition in the merger.

In additional studies we also showed that the luminosity of the electromagnetic counterpart was sensitive to thermalization efficiency of radioactive decay. We studied the nuclear physics of the elements synthesized in the merger ejecta, and determined the spectrum of decay product. We then carried out 3-dimensional transport calculations of the products -- gamma-rays, beta particles, alpha particles and fission fragments -- to determine the fraction of decay energy deposited in the ejecta. We found that the gamma and beta particles likely escape a few days after merger, and the late time emission may be powered primarily by alpha decay.

Broader Impact

Our collaborative effort helped build a technically advanced scientific workforce by training undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral scholars in research.  We also gave public talks that  disseminated the results of our research to the public at large.
